On Sep 28, 2012 5:55 AM, "Mike Kelly" <mikekelly321 <mikekelly321@...=
>
@ <mikekelly321@...>gmail.com <mikekelly321@...>> wrote:
>
> =
On Fri, Sep 28, 2012 at 9:46 AM, Ruben Verborgh <ruben.verborgh<ruben.verbo=
rgh@...>
@ <ruben.verborgh@...>ugent.be <ruben.verborgh@...>=
> wrote:
> > Hi all,
> >
> >> "Cool URIs don't change" is not a RESTful pri=
nciple.
> >
> > If there=92s no stability, how can a REST system possibly w=
ork?
> > Okay, right, hypermedia=85 (assuming that at least the starting UR=
I
remains stable)
> > but we can't expect clients to navigate to the desire=
d resource every
time again, can we?
> >
>
> yes, why not?

Retracing the h=
ypermedia trail to reset a busted bookmark when it becomes
is a Good Thing,=
 but it is not always easy or even doable.

Some interactions which are sim=
ply repeatable. Ie, I go to bookstore api,
pick the most popular book today=
 and bookmark it. The every day the app
checks and record its popularity so=
 that I can see the trend over time. If
that bookmark stops working the app=
 is pretty much screwed.

Retracing gets even harder if you have more than =
two components in the
distributed system. For example, say component A find=
s a resource and
passes its uri -- and by dong so effectively bookmarks the=
 resource -- to
component B for future processing. If the uri stops working=
 component B has
no way of acquiring the newer uri for the resource in ques=
tion since only
component A knows what hypermedia trail should be followed.=


In both of these hypothetical situations the entry point is the bookmarke=
d
uri and there is no obvious way for the clients to automatically use any
=
other entry point. There many more situations like this once you get into
b=
uilding real applications.

Peter
Barelyenough.org

--bcaec51d256087d7e704cac40a45

n Verborgh <<a href=3D"mailto:ruben.verborgh@...">ruben.verborgh</a=
><a href=3D"mailto:ruben.verborgh@...">@</a><a href=3D"mailto:ruben.ve=
rborgh@...">ugent.be</a>> wrote:<br>

> > Hi all,<br>
> &g=
t;<br>
> >> "Cool URIs don't change" is not a RESTfu=
l principle.<br>
> ><br>
> > If there=92s no stability, how can=
 a REST system possibly work?<br>
> > Okay, right, hypermedia=85 (ass=
uming that at least the starting URI remains stable)<br>
> > but we c=
an't expect clients to navigate to the desired resource every time agai=
n, can we?<br>
> ><br>
><br>
> yes, why not?</p>
<p dir=3D"ltr"=
>Retracing the hypermedia trail to reset a busted bookmark when it becomes =
is a Good Thing, but it is not always easy or even doable. </p>
<p dir=3D"l=
tr">Some interactions which are simply repeatable. Ie, I go to bookstore ap=
i, pick the most popular book today and bookmark it. The every day the app =
checks and record its popularity so that I can see the trend over time. If =
that bookmark stops working the app is pretty much screwed. </p>

<p dir=3D=
"ltr">Retracing gets even harder if you have more than two components in th=
e distributed system. For example, say component A finds a resource and pas=
ses its uri -- and by dong so effectively bookmarks the resource -- to comp=
onent B for future processing. If the uri stops working component B has no =
way of acquiring the newer uri for the resource in question since only comp=
onent A knows what hypermedia trail should be followed.</p>

<p dir=3D"ltr"=
>In both of these hypothetical situations the entry point is the bookmarked=
 uri and there is no obvious way for the clients to automatically use any o=
ther entry point. There many more situations like this once you get into bu=
ilding real applications.</p>

<p dir=3D"ltr">Peter<br>
Barelyenough.org</p=
>
